ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Ralien Catootje Bekkers  She did a great job
Instructor: Ralien Catootje Bekkers  Ralien was extremely organized and very professional. She structured the class well and invited many very interesting and informative guest speakers.
Instructor: Ralien Catootje Bekkers  Bekkers, Ralien
Instructor: Ralien Catootje Bekkers  Ralien

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Ralien Catootje Bekkers  Ralien led many of the class discussion, as well as the overall organization of the class. She did a fantastic job with it!.
Instructor: Ralien Catootje Bekkers  Very knowledgeable, good discussion leader, organized.

Instructor: Ralien Catootje Bekkers  Ralien seemed tasked with organizing pretty much every aspect of the class, and appeared to be overwhelmed as a result. The way she ran the class made a lot of sense to spread out the work and discussion leading across the students, but I think there needed to be a stronger lead. Often times it seemed like the class didn't go in the right direction or lead to major takeaways at the end. Though she did make a good effort, I don't think Ralien had the experience necessary to teach the class in the way that was demanded of her.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The class would have been so amazing if only it had more structure and rigor.
This course was led by the teaching assistant. I would have preferred more direct instruction from the professor.

Gordon didn't really teach the class at all. He also offered comments over many students and Julia, and I felt like he monopolized the discussion at times. The class needs permanent lecturer who can walk the students through each step of sustainable development implementation. Ralien (and Adam) covered the SDG process, negotiations and introductory aspects very well!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The expertise in the room (Gordon, Julia, and Ralien)
- guest speakers - history of UN environmental actions - class discussions
The field trip and guest speakers.

The field trip and some guest lectures (Susan Alzner, Jimena Leiva and perhaps David O'Connor) were the highlights. I appreciated the group that spelled out what implementation really is, and how the SDGs can be turned into actions. That should be kept. The lecture that reviewed definitions of goals, targets, indicators and the politics of the negotiations was also super helpful for understanding the basics of the process before the SDGs' adoption. I think the first week or two of classes meandered without much focus until that lecture clarified basic questions around concepts and the UN process itself.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: More structure, more content, more clarity re: assignments
- More lectures from Gordon would have been welcomed! He always had interesting input but rarely taught a whole class session himself.

I think that the classs might need to have more focus in the implementation tool for the SDG's and not so much in the global framework that surrounds the SDG's. In that sense, it might be important to take more time exploring implementing reports and methods: Logic Model, Theory of Change and others: Stakeholder engagement.
Overall structure of class time and more guidance on final paper.

There needs to be a dedicated lecturer and a more organized schedule. Also deadlines. The lack (and removal) of interim deadlines for the final paper had most of the class scrambling at the end. Despite the one on one meetings, I felt there was minimal feedback on the earlier drafts. There were a lot of readings assigned that we never covered. We also rarely reviewed the discussion questions submitted to Canvas. The only time these were brought into the classroom was during the week on business when there was nothing else to do (but I thought it was useful to discuss these questions in-person, because everyone had already put some thought into them).

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There wasn't a discussion/lab, but I think regular office hours with the TA would be helpful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: The course fits well since SDGs are the umbrella for development efforts in the following years.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: The professors and TAs teaching it
- I have worked a lot in development but have little experience with the UN and wanted more exposure to implementation techniques.
Learned more about SDGs and implementation efforts.
Aligned with my academic interest and didn't conflict with other classes.
To learn about how to translate global goals into actions on the ground.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Not really, to be honest. I felt as though this class was way too vague and lenient.
For the most part, yes, but more case studies would have been helpful for learning about different methods of implementation.

I think, more focus should be place in the implementation design, there were only two classes and its not that much time. Besides that, the chance to talk with many of the visiting speakers was great.
I learned a lot, but I would have liked for the final project to be a group assignment. I feel like the final assignment would have had more breadth and depth.

Not really. I now have a good understanding of the process, but there was only a cursory overview of means of IMPLEMENTATION, and what implementation really looks like within a country, city or region. These two aspects felt like the blind leading the blind in class, with most students approaching the questions from their entrenched ways of thinking and professional background (be it USAID, Monitoring and Evaluation, the UN, a think tank, etc) and not gaining much. I also would have liked more feedback on my initial draft paper. This was where I explored how implementation actually might happen, but I did so without much guidance.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It is a good class, although it much of it depends in what you want to take from it. I t is very student driven, if no one asks questions the class is pretty boring, so ask a lot.
Know what you want and push for it in the class, and do that early on in the semester, because the schedule changed a lot. Choose a very specific topic for your paper.
